column4: hi, i have placed a folder abs_guide which contains .html files including index.html in /var/www.However,when i point my browser to http://localhost/abs_guide/index,html, i get apache2 claims that i do not have permissions to access that page?why is this the case?
apache runs as the user www-data, make sure your files are readable by www-data
how do i do that?
The easiest (short term) way is to make them world readable.
thanks, it did work.That was easy...
How did you set the term variable?
it must have been set by ubuntu, i have never set it
were you going to help?
Oh, I'm sorry, I read that as you've already tried and it wasn't working.  Alright.  Do you want xterm-256colors or xterm-256colors-bce?
xterm-256colors
Alright, you want to add that to your ~/.profile (or ~/.bash_profile if .profile doesn't exist), to the top, add: export TERM=xterm-256colors
If you just want to set it temporarily (for this session) just use `TERM=xterm-256colors` at your prompt before running the other commands
thanks, will the latter require a reboot
Usually it's a terminal that sets it though, not your bashrc/bash profile
So, check your terminal options to see if you can set it there, that's the better way to do it
If you just use the TERM=xterm-256color at your prompt, no you don't need to restart, and it also won't save if you exit this session
gnome terminal doesnt seem to have that capability
Which capability?
to set the TERM variable as you had suggested
Which method?
I did that, and then `echo $TERM` and it still echoe xterm, i rebooted, no difference.what could be the problem?
